guide.introduction: I've noticed that an Altoids tin can be used to make many a small project, but I have not found many Altoids-tin heaters. So I gave it a try, and to make your own just follow this project.
guide.introduction_rendered:
I've noticed that an Altoids tin can be used to make many a small project, but I have not found many Altoids-tin heaters. So I gave it a try, and to make your own just follow this project.

Relevant parts
  • altoids tin, or make project tin.
  • small metal brackets, or scrap metal
  • Matches
  • Tea Light
Tools
  • Dremel tool with metal cutting, and grinding, heads.
  • Needle Nose Pliers
  • Soldering iron

parts.text: altoids tin, or make project tin.
small metal brackets, or scrap metal

lines.text: Mark the scrap metal, or the brackets, to the appropriate width and height for the candle and the tin.
lines.text_raw: Mark the scrap metal, or the brackets, to the appropriate width and height for the candle and the tin.

lines.text: Now use the Dremel to cut the metal, and grind any rough edges.
lines.text_raw: Now use the Dremel to cut the metal, and grind any rough edges.

lines.text: Now place the brackets to one side of the tin, and create a space large enogh for the tea light.
lines.text_raw: Now place the brackets to one side of the tin, and create a space large enogh for the tea light.

lines.text: REMEMBER to leave enough space on the other side for the matches.
lines.text_raw: '''REMEMBER''' to leave enough space on the other side for the matches.

lines.text: Then solder the brackets in place. Make sure they are secure.
lines.text_raw: Then solder the brackets in place. Make sure they are secure.

lines.text: Remember to solder in a well-ventilated area as fumes can be dangerous.
lines.text_raw: '''Remember''' to solder in a well-ventilated area as fumes can be dangerous.

lines.text: Now insert the tea light and the matches into the tin.
lines.text_raw: Now insert the tea light and the matches into the tin.

lines.text: For an extra test you can bend a makeshift holder out of any leftover metal and heat a small amount of water over the flame.
